heading: Births
txt: Jonathan Potter, English psychologist, sociolinguist, and academic

entities.title: Jonathan Potter
entities.description: Jonathan Potter is Dean of the School of Communication and Information at Rutgers University and one of the originators of discursive psychology.

heading: Births
txt: Scott Adams, American author and illustrator

entities.title: Scott Adams
entities.description:
Scott Raymond Adams is an American artist and creator of the Dilbert comic strip and the author of several nonfiction works of satire, commentary, and business.
His Dilbert series came to national prominence through the downsizing period in 1990s America and was then distributed worldwide. Adams worked in various roles at big businesses before he became a full-time cartoonist in 1995. He writes in

heading: Births
txt: Don Robinson, American baseball player and politician

heading: Births
txt: Sonja Vectomov, Czech/Finnish sculptor

heading: Births
txt: Louise Richardson, Irish political scientist and academic

entities.title: Louise Richardson
entities.description: Louise Mary Richardson FRSE is an Irish political scientist whose specialist field is the study of terrorism. In January 2016 she became the Vice-Chancellor of the University of Oxford, having formerly served as the Principal and Vice-Chancellor of the University of St Andrews, and as the executive dean of the Radcliffe Institute for Advanced Study at Harvard University.

heading: Births
txt: Keenen Ivory Wayans, American actor, director, and screenwriter

heading: Births
txt: Mohsen Kadivar, Iranian philosopher

entities.title: Mohsen Kadivar
entities.description: Mohsen Kadivar is a philosopher, leading intellectual reformist, and professor of Islamic Studies. A political Iranian dissident, Kadivar has been a vocal critic of the doctrine of clerical rule, also known as Velayat-e Faqih, and a strong advocate of democratic and liberal reforms in Iran as well as constructional reform in shari'a and Shi'a theology. Kadivar has served time in prison in Iran for

heading: Births
txt: Mick Hucknall, English singer-songwriter

entities.title: Mick Hucknall
entities.description: Michael James Hucknall is an English singer and songwriter. Hucknall achieved international fame in the 1980s as the lead singer and songwriter of the soul-influenced pop band Simply Red, with whom he enjoyed a 25-year career and sold over 50 million albums. Hucknall was described by Australian music magazine Rhythms as "one of the truly great blue-eyed soul singers", while Q credited him with "th

heading: Births
txt: Thomas Steen, Swedish ice hockey player and coach

heading: Births
txt: Mary Bonauto, American lawyer and gay rights activist

entities.title: Mary Bonauto
entities.description:
Mary L. Bonauto is an American lawyer and civil rights advocate who has worked to eradicate discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity, and has been referred to by US Representative Barney Frank as "our Thurgood Marshall."
She began working with the Massachusetts-based Gay & Lesbian Advocates & Defenders, now named GLBTQ Legal Advocates & Defenders (GLAD) organization in 1990.

heading: Births
txt: Karen Kingsbury, American journalist and author

entities.title: Karen Kingsbury
entities.description: Karen Kingsbury is an American Christian novelist born in Fairfax, Virginia.

heading: Births
txt: Butch Reynolds, American runner and coach

entities.title: Butch Reynolds
entities.description: Harry Lee Reynolds Jr., commonly known as Butch Reynolds, is an American former track and field athlete who competed in the 400 meter dash. He held the world record for the event for 11 years with his personal best time of 43.29 seconds set in 1988. That year, he was the silver medalist at the 1988 Seoul Olympics and a relay gold medalist. He was falsely accused and banned for drug use for two yea

heading: Births
txt: Kevin Farley, American screenwriter

entities.title: Kevin Farley
entities.description: Kevin Peter Farley is an American actor, comedian, writer, producer and director.

heading: Births
txt: Russell E. Morris, Welsh chemist and academic

entities.title: Russell E. Morris
entities.description: Russell Edward Morris is Bishop Wardlaw Professor of Chemistry at the University of St Andrews. He played first-class cricket while he was a student at the University of Oxford. He also represented the University of Oxford at Association Football (soccer) playing in Varsity matches at various venues, including Wembley Stadium and Highbury, the home of Arsenal Football Club.

heading: Births
txt: Mark Feuerstein, American actor, director, and producer

entities.title: Mark Feuerstein
entities.description: Mark Feuerstein is an American actor, writer, producer and director. He first came to public notice in a guest appearance in an episode of Season 2 of Sex and the City and went on to appear in TV series The West Wing (2001–2005), Royal Pains (2009–2016) and Prison Break (2017). He co-wrote, co-produced as well as starred in the short-lived CBS sitcom 9JKL.

heading: Births
txt: Kanye West, American rapper, producer, director, and fashion designer

entities.title: Kanye West
entities.description: Kanye Omari West is an American rapper, record producer, businessman, fashion designer, and politician. He has been influential in the 21st-century development of mainstream hip hop and popular music in general.

heading: Births
txt: Rachel Held Evans, American Christian author (d. 2019)

entities.title: Rachel Held Evans
entities.description: Rachel Held Evans was an American Christian columnist, blogger and author. Her book A Year of Biblical Womanhood was a New York Times bestseller in e-book non-fiction, and Searching for Sunday was a New York Times bestseller nonfiction paperback.

heading: Births
txt: Nadia Petrova, Russian tennis player

entities.title: Nadia Petrova
entities.description: Nadezhda Viktorovna "Nadia" Petrova is a Russian former professional tennis player. A former top 5 player in both singles and doubles, she reached a career-high ranking of No. 3 in the world in both disciplines. Petrova won a total of 37 titles on the WTA Tour in her career, 13 in singles and 24 in doubles, as well as over $12.4 million in prize money, making her one of the most successful Russian

heading: Births
txt: Kim Clijsters, Belgian tennis player; winner of six Grand Slam tournament titles.

entities.title: Kim Clijsters
entities.description: Kim Antonie Lode Clijsters is a Belgian professional tennis player. Clijsters has been a world No. 1 in both singles and doubles, having held both rankings simultaneously in 2003. She has won a total of six Grand Slam tournament titles, four in singles and two in doubles.

entities.title: Grand Slam (tennis)
entities.description: The Grand Slam tournaments, also referred to as majors, are the world's four most important annual tennis events. The tournaments offer the most ranking points, prize money, public and media attention, the greatest strength and size of field, and greater number of "best of" sets for men, which is 5. The Grand Slam itinerary consists of the Australian Open in mid January, the French Open from late

heading: Births
txt: Javier Mascherano, Argentinian footballer

entities.title: Javier Mascherano
entities.description: Javier Alejandro Mascherano is an Argentine former professional footballer who played as a defensive midfielder or centre-back.

heading: Births
txt: Timea Bacsinszky, Swiss tennis player

entities.title: Timea Bacsinszky
entities.description: Timea Bacsinszky is a Swiss professional tennis player who has won four WTA singles and five doubles titles, as well as 13 ITF singles and 14 doubles titles. A former top ten singles player, Bacsinszky reached a career-high singles ranking of world No. 9 on 16 May 2016.

heading: Births
txt: Jeļena Ostapenko, Latvian tennis player

entities.title: Jeļena Ostapenko
entities.description: Jeļena Ostapenko, also known as Aļona Ostapenko, is a professional tennis player from Latvia. She has career-high WTA rankings of No. 5 in singles, achieved on 19 March 2018, and No. 17 in doubles, reached on 2 March 2020.

heading: Deaths
txt: Muhammad, the central figure of Islam, widely regarded as its founder (b. 570/571)

entities.title: Muhammad
entities.description: Muhammad was an Arab religious, social, and political leader and the founder of the world religion of Islam. According to Islamic doctrine, he was a prophet, sent to preach and confirm the monotheistic teachings of Adam, Abraham, Moses, Jesus, and other prophets. He is believed to be the final prophet of God in all the main branches of Islam, though some modern denominations diverge from this beli

heading: Deaths
txt: Chlodulf, bishop of Metz (or 697)

entities.title: Chlodulf of Metz
entities.description: Saint Chlodulf was bishop of Metz approximately from 657 to 697.

entities.title: Roman Catholic Diocese of Metz
entities.description: The Roman Catholic Diocese of Metz is a diocese of the Latin Rite of the Roman Catholic Church in France. In the Middle Ages it was a prince-bishopric of the Holy Roman Empire, a de facto independent state ruled by the prince-bishop who had the ex officio title of count. It was annexed to France by King Henry II in 1552; this was recognized by the Holy Roman Empire in the Peace of Westphalia of 16

heading: Deaths
txt: Zhao Ying, Chinese chancellor (b. 885)

entities.title: Zhao Ying
entities.description: Zhao Ying, courtesy name Yuanhui (元輝), was an official of the Chinese Five Dynasties and Ten Kingdoms Period states Later Tang and Later Jin, serving as a chancellor during Later Jin.

heading: Deaths
txt: Harthacnut, English-Danish king (b. 1018)

entities.title: Harthacnut
entities.description: Harthacnut, sometimes referred to as Canute III, was King of Denmark from 1035 to 1042 and King of England from 1040 to 1042.

heading: Deaths
txt: William of York, English archbishop and saint

entities.title: William of York
entities.description: William of York was an English priest, and unusually twice Archbishop of York, before and after his rival Henry Murdac. He was thought to be related to King Stephen of England, who helped to secure his election to the province after several candidates had failed to gain papal confirmation. William faced opposition from the Cistercians, who after the election of the Cistercian Pope Eugene III, had

heading: Deaths
txt: Beatrice Portinari, object of Dante Alighieri's adoration (b. 1266)

entities.title: Beatrice Portinari
entities.description: Beatrice "Bice" di Folco Portinari was an Italian woman who has been commonly identified as the principal inspiration for Dante Alighieri's Vita Nuova, and is also commonly identified with the Beatrice who appears as one of his guides in the last book of the Divine Comedy, Paradiso, and in the last four canti of Purgatorio. There she takes over as guide from the Latin poet Virgil because, as a pag

entities.title: Dante Alighieri
entities.description: Dante Alighieri, probably baptized Durante di Alighiero degli Alighieri and often referred to simply as Dante, was an Italian poet, writer and philosopher. His Divine Comedy, originally called Comedìa and later christened Divina by Giovanni Boccaccio, is widely considered the most important poem of the Middle Ages and the greatest literary work in the Italian language.

heading: Deaths
txt: Edward, the Black Prince, English son of Edward III of England (b. 1330)

entities.title: Edward, the Black Prince
entities.description: Edward of Woodstock, known to history as the Black Prince, was the eldest son of King Edward III of England, and the heir to the English throne. He died before his father and so his son, Richard II, succeeded to the throne instead. Edward nevertheless earned distinction as one of the most successful English commanders during the Hundred Years' War, being regarded by his English contemporaries as a

entities.title: Edward III of England
entities.description: Edward III, also known as Edward of Windsor before his accession, was King of England and Lord of Ireland from January 1327 until his death in 1377. He is noted for his military success and for restoring royal authority after the disastrous and unorthodox reign of his father, Edward II. Edward III transformed the Kingdom of England into one of the most formidable military powers in Europe. His fif

heading: Deaths
txt: Thomas de Ros, 4th Baron de Ros, English politician (b. 1338)

entities.title: Thomas de Ros, 4th Baron de Ros
entities.description: Thomas Ros, 4th Baron Ros of Helmsley was the son of William Ros, 2nd Baron Ros and Margery de Badlesmere.

heading: Deaths
txt: Kan'ami, Japanese actor and playwright (b. 1333)

entities.title: Kan'ami
entities.description: Kan'ami Kiyotsugu  was a Japanese Noh actor, author, and musician during the Muromachi period. Born Yūzaki Kiyotsugu  in Iga Province, Kan'ami also went by Miyomaru (観世丸) and Kanze Kiyotsugu . He is the father of the well-known playwright Zeami Motokiyo .

heading: Deaths
txt: Richard le Scrope, Archbishop of York (b. c.1350)

entities.title: Richard Scrope (bishop)
entities.description: Richard le Scrope was an English cleric who served as Bishop of Lichfield and Archbishop of York and was executed in 1405 for his participation in the Northern Rising against King Henry IV.

heading: Deaths
txt: Thomas de Mowbray, 4th Earl of Norfolk (b. 1385)

heading: Deaths
txt: George Neville, English archbishop and academic (b. 1432)

entities.title: George Neville (bishop)
entities.description: George Neville was Archbishop of York from 1465 until 1476 and Chancellor of England from 1460 until 1467 and again from 1470 until 1471.

heading: Deaths
txt: Elizabeth Woodville, Queen consort of England (b. 1437)

entities.title: Elizabeth Woodville
entities.description: Elizabeth Woodville was Queen of England as the spouse of King Edward IV from 1464 until his death in 1483.

heading: Deaths
txt: George Gordon, 2nd Earl of Huntly, Earl of Huntly and Lord Chancellor of Scotland (b. 1440)

entities.title: George Gordon, 2nd Earl of Huntly
entities.description: George Gordon, 2nd Earl of Huntly was a Scottish nobleman and Chancellor of Scotland from 1498–1501.

heading: Deaths
txt: Hongzhi Emperor of China (b. 1470)

entities.title: Hongzhi Emperor
entities.description: The Hongzhi Emperor was the 10th Emperor of the Ming dynasty, reigned from 1487 to 1505. Born Zhu Youcheng, he was the eldest surviving son of the Chenghua Emperor and his reign as emperor of China is called the "Hongzhi Silver Age". His era name, "Hongzhi", means "great government." A peace-loving emperor, the Hongzhi Emperor also had only one empress and no concubines, granting him the distincti

heading: Deaths
txt: Edward Fortunatus, German nobleman (b. 1565)

entities.title: Edward Fortunatus
entities.description: Edward Fortunatus of Baden was Margrave of Baden-Rodemachern and Baden-Baden.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jean Bertaut, French bishop and poet (b. 1552)

entities.title: Jean Bertaut
entities.description: Jean Bertaut, French poet, was born at Caen.

heading: Deaths
txt: Hans Leo Hassler, German organist and composer (b. 1562)

entities.title: Hans Leo Hassler
entities.description: Hans Leo Hassler was a German composer and organist of the late Renaissance and early Baroque eras, elder brother of composer Jakob Hassler. He was born in Nuremberg and died in Frankfurt am Main.

heading: Deaths
txt: Anne de Xainctonge, French saint, founded the Society of the Sisters of Saint Ursula of the Blessed Virgin (b. 1567)

entities.title: Anne de Xainctonge
entities.description: Anne de Xainctonge was a French religious sister who founded of the Society of the Sisters of Saint Ursula of the Blessed Virgin, the first non-cloistered women's religious community. She was declared Venerable by the Roman Catholic Church in 1991.

entities.title: Society of the Sisters of Saint Ursula of the Blessed Virgin
entities.description: The Society of the Sisters of Saint Ursula of the Blessed Virgin is a Roman Catholic religious congregation of women founded in 1606 at Döle, France, by the Venerable Anne de Xainctonge (1587-1612). Its members are especially involved in teaching.

heading: Deaths
txt: Rudolph Goclenius, German lexicographer and philosopher (b. 1547)

entities.title: Rudolph Goclenius
entities.description: Rudolph Goclenius the Elder was a German scholastic philosopher. Gockel is often credited with coining the term "psychology" in 1590, though the term had been used by Marko Marulić at least 66 years earlier. heading: Deaths
txt: Tokugawa Iemitsu, Japanese shōgun (b. 1604)

entities.title: Tokugawa Iemitsu
entities.description: Tokugawa Iemitsu was the third shōgun of the Tokugawa dynasty. He was the eldest son of Tokugawa Hidetada with Oeyo, and the grandson of Tokugawa Ieyasu. Lady Kasuga was his wet nurse, who acted as his political adviser and was at the forefront of shogunate negotiations with the Imperial court. Iemitsu ruled from 1623 to 1651; during this period he crucified Christians, expelled all Europeans from

heading: Deaths
txt: Sophia of Hanover (b. 1630)

entities.title: Sophia of Hanover
entities.description: Sophia of Hanover was the Electress of Hanover by marriage to Elector Ernest Augustus, and later the heiress presumptive to the thrones of England and Ireland under the Act of Settlement 1701. She died less than two months before she would have become queen. Consequently, it was her son George I who succeeded her first cousin once removed, Anne.

heading: Deaths
txt: Johann Wilhelm, Elector Palatine, German son of Landgravine Elisabeth Amalie of Hesse-Darmstadt (b. 1658)

entities.title: Johann Wilhelm, Elector Palatine
entities.description: Johann Wilhelm II, Elector Palatine of the Wittelsbach dynasty was Elector Palatine (1690–1716), Duke of Neuburg (1690–1716), Duke of Jülich and Berg (1679–1716), and Duke of Upper Palatinate and Cham (1707–1714). From 1697 onwards Johann Wilhelm was also Count of Megen.

entities.title: Landgravine Elisabeth Amalie of Hesse-Darmstadt
entities.description: Landgravine Elisabeth Amalie of Hesse-Darmstadt was a princess of Hesse-Darmstadt and wife of the Prince-elector of the Palatinate.

heading: Deaths
txt: August Hermann Francke, German-Lutheran pietist, philanthropist, and scholar (b. 1663)

entities.title: August Hermann Francke
entities.description: August Hermann Francke was a German Lutheran clergyman, theologian, philanthropist, and Biblical scholar.

heading: Deaths
txt: Johann Joachim Winckelmann, German archaeologist and scholar (b. 1717)

entities.title: Johann Joachim Winckelmann
entities.description: Johann Joachim Winckelmann was a German art historian and archaeologist. He was a pioneering Hellenist who first articulated the difference between Greek, Greco-Roman and Roman art. "The prophet and founding hero of modern archaeology", Winckelmann was one of the founders of scientific archaeology and first applied the categories of style on a large, systematic basis to the history of art. Many co

heading: Deaths
txt: George Montagu-Dunk, 2nd Earl of Halifax, English politician, Lord Lieutenant of Ireland (b. 1716)

entities.title: George Montagu-Dunk, 2nd Earl of Halifax
entities.description: George Montagu-Dunk, 2nd Earl of Halifax, was a British statesman of the Georgian era. Due to his success in extending American commerce he became known as "father of the colonies". President of the Board of Trade from 1748 to 1761, he aided the foundation of Nova Scotia, 1749, the capital Halifax being named after him.

entities.title: Lord Lieutenant of Ireland
entities.description: Lord Lieutenant of Ireland, or more formally Lord Lieutenant General and General Governor of Ireland, was the title of the chief governor of Ireland from the Williamite Wars of 1690 until the Partition of Ireland in 1922. This spanned the Kingdom of Ireland (1541–1800) and the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland (1801–1922). The office, under its various names, was often more generally kno

heading: Deaths
txt: Louis XVII of France (b. 1785)

entities.title: Louis XVII of France
entities.description: Louis XVII was the younger son of King Louis XVI of France and Queen Marie Antoinette. His older brother, Louis Joseph, Dauphin of France, died in June 1789, a little over a month before the start of the French Revolution. At his brother's death he became the new Dauphin, a title he held until 1791, when the new constitution accorded the heir apparent the style of Prince Royal.

heading: Deaths
txt: Thomas Paine, English-American theorist and author (b. 1737)

entities.title: Thomas Paine
entities.description: Thomas Paine was an English-born American political activist, philosopher, political theorist, and revolutionary. He authored Common Sense (1776) and The American Crisis (1776–1783), the two most influential pamphlets at the start of the American Revolution, and helped inspire the patriots in 1776 to declare independence from Great Britain. His ideas reflected Enlightenment-era ideals of transnati

heading: Deaths
txt: Sarah Siddons, Welsh actress (b. 1755)

entities.title: Sarah Siddons
entities.description: Sarah Siddons was a Welsh-born English actress, the best-known tragedienne of the 18th century. Contemporaneous critic William Hazlitt dubbed Siddons as "tragedy personified".

heading: Deaths
txt: Gian Domenico Romagnosi, Italian economist and jurist (b. 1761)

entities.title: Gian Domenico Romagnosi
entities.description: Gian Domenico Romagnosi was an Italian philosopher, economist and jurist.

heading: Deaths
txt: Andrew Jackson, American general, judge, and politician, 7th President of the United States (b. 1767)

entities.title: Andrew Jackson
entities.description: Andrew Jackson was an American lawyer, soldier, and statesman who served as the seventh president of the United States from 1829 to 1837. Before being elected to the presidency, Jackson gained fame as a general in the United States Army and served in both houses of the U.S. Congress. An expansionist president, Jackson sought to advance the rights of the "common man" against a "corrupt aristocracy"

entities.title: President of the United States
entities.description: The president of the United States (POTUS) is the head of state and head of government of the United States of America. The president directs the executive branch of the federal government and is the commander-in-chief of the United States Armed Forces.

heading: Deaths
txt: Rodolphe Töpffer, Swiss teacher, author, painter, cartoonist, and caricaturist (b. 1799)

entities.title: Rodolphe Töpffer
entities.description: Rodolphe Töpffer was a Swiss teacher, author, painter, cartoonist, and caricaturist. He is best known for his illustrated books, which are possibly the earliest European comics. He is known as the father of comic strips and has been credited as the "first comics artist in history."

heading: Deaths
txt: Douglas William Jerrold, English journalist and playwright (b. 1803)

entities.title: Douglas William Jerrold
entities.description: Douglas William Jerrold was an English dramatist and writer.

heading: Deaths
txt: Cochise, American tribal chief (b. 1805)

entities.title: Cochise
entities.description: Cochise was leader of the Chihuicahui local group of the Chokonen and principal chief of the Chokonen band of the Chiricahua Apache. A key war leader during the Apache Wars, he led an uprising which began in 1861 and persisted until a peace treaty was negotiated in 1872. Cochise County, Arizona, is named after him.

heading: Deaths
txt: George Sand, French author and playwright (b. 1804)

entities.title: George Sand
entities.description: Amantine Lucile Aurore Dupin, best known by her pen name George Sand, was a French novelist, memoirist, and journalist. One of the most popular writers in Europe in her lifetime, being more renowned than both Victor Hugo and Honoré de Balzac in England in the 1830s and 1840s, Sand is recognised as one of the most notable writers of the European Romantic era.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ignace Bourget, Canadian bishop (b. 1799)

entities.title: Ignace Bourget
entities.description: Ignace Bourget was a Canadian Roman Catholic priest who held the title of Bishop of Montreal from 1840 to 1876. Born in Lévis, Quebec in 1799, Bourget entered the clergy at an early age, undertook several courses of religious study, and in 1837 was named co-adjutor bishop of the newly created bishopric of Montreal. Following the death of Jean-Jacques Lartigue in 1840, Bourget became Bishop of Mont

heading: Deaths
txt: Gerard Manley Hopkins, English poet (b. 1844)

entities.title: Gerard Manley Hopkins
entities.description: Gerard Manley Hopkins was an English poet and Jesuit priest, whose posthumous fame established him among the leading Victorian poets. His manipulation of prosody – particularly his concept of sprung rhythm – established him as an innovative writer of verse, as did his technique of praising God through vivid use of imagery and nature. Only after his death did Robert Bridges begin to publish a few o

heading: Deaths
txt: Mary of the Divine Heart, German nun and saint (b. 1863)

entities.title: Mary of the Divine Heart
entities.description: Mary of the Divine Heart, born Maria Droste zu Vischering, was a German noblewoman and Roman Catholic nun of the Congregation of Our Lady of Charity of the Good Shepherd, best known for having influenced Pope Leo XIII to make the consecration of the world to the Sacred Heart of Jesus. Pope Leo XIII himself called the solemn consecration "the greatest act of my pontificate".

heading: Deaths
txt: Andrew Irvine, English mountaineer and explorer (b. 1902)

entities.title: Andrew Irvine (mountaineer)
entities.description: Andrew Comyn "Sandy" Irvine was an English mountaineer who took part in the 1924 British Everest Expedition, the third British expedition to the world's highest mountain, Mount Everest.

heading: Deaths
txt: George Mallory, English lieutenant and mountaineer (b. 1886)

heading: Deaths
txt: Bliss Carman, Canadian-American poet and playwright (b. 1861)

entities.title: Bliss Carman
entities.description: William Bliss Carman was a Canadian poet who lived most of his life in the United States, where he achieved international fame. He was acclaimed as Canada's poet laureate during his later years.

heading: Deaths
txt: Karl Hanke, Polish-German soldier and politician (b. 1903)

entities.title: Karl Hanke
entities.description: Karl August Hanke was an official of the Nazi Party (NSDAP) during its rule over Germany and served as the fifth and last Reichsführer of the Schutzstaffel (SS). He also served as Gauleiter of Gau Lower Silesia from 1941 to 1945 and as Oberpräsident of the Prussian Province of Lower Silesia. Captured on 6 May 1945, he was shot and killed by Czech partisans on 8 June.

heading: Deaths
txt: Eugène Fiset, Canadian physician, general, and politician, 18th Lieutenant Governor of Quebec (b. 1874)

entities.title: Eugène Fiset
entities.description: Major-General Sir Marie-Joseph-Eugène Fiset, was a Canadian physician, military officer, Deputy Minister of Militia and Defence, Member of Parliament, the 18th Lieutenant Governor of Quebec, and the 3rd Canadian Surgeon General.

entities.title: Lieutenant Governor of Quebec
entities.description: The Lieutenant Governor of Quebec is the viceregal representative in Quebec of the Canadian monarch, Queen Elizabeth II, who operates distinctly within the province but is also shared equally with the ten other jurisdictions of Canada, as well as the other Commonwealth realms and any subdivisions thereof, and resides predominantly in her oldest realm, the United Kingdom. heading: Deaths
txt: Oswald Pohl, German SS officer (b. 1892)

entities.title: SS
entities.description: The Schutzstaffel was a major paramilitary organization under Adolf Hitler and the Nazi Party in Nazi Germany, and later throughout German-occupied Europe during World War II. It began with a small guard unit known as the Saal-Schutz made up of party volunteers to provide security for party meetings in Munich. In 1925, Heinrich Himmler joined the unit, which had by then been reformed and given its

heading: Deaths
txt: Marie Laurencin, French painter and sculptor (b. 1883)

entities.title: Marie Laurencin
entities.description: Marie Laurencin was a French painter and printmaker. She became an important figure in the Parisian avant-garde as a member of the Cubists associated with the Section d'Or.

heading: Deaths
txt: Leslie Johnson, English race car driver (b. 1912)

entities.title: Leslie Johnson (racing driver)
entities.description: Leslie George Johnson was a British racing driver who competed in rallies, hill climbs, sports car races and Grand Prix races.

heading: Deaths
txt: Edmondo Rossoni, Italian politician (b. 1884)

entities.title: Edmondo Rossoni
entities.description: Edmondo Rossoni was a revolutionary syndicalist leader and an Italian fascist politician who became involved in the Fascist syndicate movement during Benito Mussolini's regime.

heading: Deaths
txt: Anton Melik, Slovenian geographer and academic (b. 1890)

entities.title: Anton Melik
entities.description: Anton Melik was a Slovene geographer.

heading: Deaths
txt: Elizabeth Enright, American author and illustrator (b. 1909)

entities.title: Elizabeth Enright
entities.description: Elizabeth Wright Enright Gillham was an American writer of children's books, an illustrator, writer of short stories for adults, literary critic and teacher of creative writing. Perhaps best known as the Newbery Medal-winning author of Thimble Summer (1938) and the Newbery runner-up Gone-Away Lake (1957), she also wrote the popular Melendy quartet. heading: Deaths
txt: Abraham Maslow, American psychologist and academic (b. 1908)

entities.title: Abraham Maslow
entities.description: Abraham Harold Maslow was an American psychologist who was best known for creating Maslow's hierarchy of needs, a theory of psychological health predicated on fulfilling innate human needs in priority, culminating in self-actualization. Maslow was a psychology professor at Brandeis University, Brooklyn College, New School for Social Research, and Columbia University. He stressed the importance of

heading: Deaths
txt: J.I. Rodale, American author and playwright (b. 1898)

entities.title: J.I. Rodale
entities.description: Jerome Irving Rodale was a publisher, editor, author, playwright, and founder of Rodale, Inc. He was an early advocate of sustainable agriculture and organic farming in the United States. As an author, his work included several magazines and books, including books featuring different authors, on the subject of health. He popularized the term "organic" as a term for growing food without pesticides.

entities.title: Thorleif Schjelderup-Ebbe
entities.description: Thorleif Schjelderup-Ebbe was a Norwegian zoologist and comparative psychologist.

heading: Deaths
txt: Satchel Paige, American baseball player and coach (b. 1906)

entities.title: Satchel Paige
entities.description: Leroy Robert "Satchel" Paige was an American professional baseball pitcher who played in Negro league baseball and Major League Baseball (MLB). His career spanned five decades and culminated with his induction into the National Baseball Hall of Fame.

heading: Deaths
txt: Gordon Jacob, English composer and academic (b. 1895)

entities.title: Gordon Jacob
entities.description: Gordon Percival Septimus Jacob CBE was an English composer and teacher. He was a professor at the Royal College of Music in London from 1924 until his retirement in 1966, and published four books and many articles about music. heading: Deaths
txt: Alexander Iolas, Egyptian-American art collector (b. 1907)

entities.title: Alexander Iolas
entities.description: Alexander Iolas or Alexandre Iolas was a Greek gallerist and collector. He owned galleries in the United States and Europe and contributed in many private and public art collections.

heading: Deaths
txt: George Turner, Australian author and critic (b. 1916)

entities.title: George Turner (writer)
entities.description: George Reginald Turner was an Australian writer and critic, best known for the science fiction novels written in the later part of his career. His first science fiction story and novel appeared in 1978, when he was in his early sixties. By this point, however, he had already achieved success as a mainstream novelist, including a Miles Franklin Award, and as a literary critic.

heading: Deaths

heading: Deaths
txt: Sani Abacha, Nigerian general and politician, 10th President of Nigeria (b. 1943)

entities.title: Sani Abacha
entities.description: Sani Abacha GCFR was a Nigerian military general who served as the military head of state of Nigeria from 1993 until his death in 1998. He was also Chief of Army Staff between 1985 to 1990; Chief of Defence Staff between 1990 to 1993; and Minister of Defence. In 1993, Abacha became the first Nigerian Army officer to attain the rank of a full military general without skipping a single rank.

entities.title: President of Nigeria
entities.description: The president of the Federal Republic of Nigeria is the head of state and head of government of the Federal Republic of Nigeria. The president of Nigeria is also the commander-in-chief of the Nigerian Armed Forces. The president is elected in national elections which take place every four years. The offices, powers, and titles of the head of state and the head of government were officially merged

entities.title: Frédéric Dard
entities.description: Frédéric Dard was a French crime writer. He wrote more than three hundred novels, plays and screenplays, under his own name and a variety of pseudonyms, including the San-Antonio book series.

entities.title: Jaxon
entities.description: Jack Edward Jackson, better known by his pen name Jaxon, was an American cartoonist, illustrator, historian, and writer. He co-founded Rip Off Press, and some consider him to be the first underground comix artist, due to his most well-known comic strip God Nose.

entities.title: Rip Off Press
entities.description: Rip Off Press, Inc. is a mail order retailer and distributor, better known as the former publisher of "adult-themed" series like The Fabulous Furry Freak Brothers and Rip Off Comix, as well as many other seminal publications from the underground comix era. heading: Deaths
txt: Šaban Bajramović, Serbian singer-songwriter (b. 1936)

entities.title: Šaban Bajramović
entities.description: Šaban Bajramović, nicknamed Šabi (Шаби), was a Serbian vocalist and recording artist of Romani ethnicity. He was one of the most internationally critically acclaimed Romani singer-songwriters. Due to his eminent impact on music in Eastern Europe, he was dubbed the "King of Romani music".

heading: Deaths
txt: Omar Bongo, Gabonese captain and politician, President of Gabon (b. 1935)

entities.title: Omar Bongo
entities.description: El Hadj Omar Bongo Ondimba was a Gabonese politician who was the second President of Gabon for 42 years, from 1967 until his death in 2009. Omar Bongo was promoted to key positions as a young official under Gabon's first President Léon M'ba in the 1960s, before being elected Vice-President in his own right in 1966. In 1967, he succeeded M'ba to become the second Gabon President, upon the latter's

entities.title: President of Gabon
entities.description: This is a list of presidents of Gabon since the formation of the post of president in 1960, to the present day.

txt: Crispian St. Peters, English singer-songwriter (b. 1939)

entities.title: Crispian St. Peters
entities.description: Crispian St. Peters was an English pop singer-songwriter, best known for his work in the 1960s, particularly hit songs written by duo The Changin' Times, including "The Pied Piper" and Ian & Sylvia's "You Were on My Mind".

heading: Deaths
txt: Paul Cellucci, American soldier and politician, 69th Governor of Massachusetts (b. 1948)

entities.title: Paul Cellucci
entities.description: Argeo Paul Cellucci was an American politician and diplomat from Massachusetts. A Republican, he served as the 69th governor of Massachusetts from 1999 to 2001, and as the United States Ambassador to Canada from 2001 to 2005. He also served as the state's 68th lieutenant governor from 1991 to 1999, as well as in the Massachusetts House of Representatives and Senate from 1977 to 1991.

entities.title: Governor of Massachusetts
entities.description: The Governor of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, is the head of state and head of government of Massachusetts and is charged with enforcing state laws. The governor is the chief of the executive branch of the government of Massachusetts and is the commander-in-chief of the commonwealth's military forces.

entities.title: First Spouse of Indonesia
entities.description: Throughout Indonesian history, the title of First Lady or, in an instance, First Gentleman has been used to refer to the wife or husband of the president of Indonesia. While the Constitution of Indonesia does not mention anything about the spouses of the president, it continues to hold significant influence in the Indonesian society.

heading: Deaths

entities.title: Alexander Imich
entities.description: Alexander Imich was a Polish-American chemist, parapsychologist, zoologist and writer who was the president of the Anomalous Phenomena Research Center in New York City. He was born in 1903 in Częstochowa, Poland to a Jewish family.

heading: Deaths
txt: Chea Sim, Cambodian commander and politician (b. 1932)

entities.title: Chea Sim
entities.description: Chea Sim was a Cambodian politician. He was President of the Cambodian People's Party from 1991 to 2015, President of the National Assembly of Cambodia from 1981 to 1998 and President of the Senate from 1999 to 2015. His official title was Samdach Akeak Moha Thomak Pothisal Chea Sim, Prathean Protsaphea ney Preah Reacheanachak Kampuchea.

entities.title: Sam Panopoulos
entities.description: Sotirios "Sam" Panopoulos was a Greek-born Canadian cook and businessman, credited as the inventor of Hawaiian pizza.

heading: Deaths
txt: Andre Matos, Brazilian heavy metal musician (b. 1971)

entities.title: Andre Matos
entities.description: André Coelho Matos was a Brazilian singer, musician, producer, and composer. He was involved in the heavy metal bands Viper, Angra, Shaman and Symfonia and sold millions of copies worldwide. Since October 2006, Matos had been dedicating his time to his solo career. In 2012, he was ranked No. 77 at the list of 100 Greatest Voices of Brazilian Music by Rolling Stone Brasil.
